Danijel Arsenovski wrote:

> Hi,
> 
> I started writing some tests for my app in C#, and I am using NUnit 
> (hope it's OK to post here, NUnit is just a transcript of JUnit).
> My problem is that when I test code that ends up modifying a DB, I need 
> to restore DB every time I finish my tests and that is not allways 
> possible and it takes time.
> Is there other way to do this, like using mock objects. I started 
> constructing DataSets from code, but needs really lot of code ant that's 
> getting tedious.
> Any suggestions?

Google "Dalloway unit test database" and read the article. It's a very 
good one.

I had a nice article on this, but a hard disk failure wiped it out. I 
need a better backup strategy.

Some quick comments.

1. Restoring the database is /always/ possible.
2. Restoring the database indeed takes time.
3. The more isolated your tests, the less you need to worry about the 
database.

Test your business logic without worrying about where the data comes 
from. Test your data access objects with a mock database client. Test 
your /real/ database client (a generic query builder and query executer) 
against a real database.

Note: the time you spend writing more code to do everything in memory 
will be returned to you by avoiding spending extra time /executing/ 
tests that use a real database.
